vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/edcf9d6d-1409-4a55-9913-ec0fd8e49c4f">WEALTH</keyword>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Northern Ireland Life and Times Survey</i> (NILT) series began in 1998, and was the successor to the previous <i>Northern Ireland Social Attitudes</i> series, (held at the UK Data Archive under SN 33235), which was discontinued in 1996. The aims of the NILT series are:<ul><li>to monitor public attitudes towards social policy and political issues in Northern Ireland</li><li>to provide a time series on attitudes to key social policy areas</li><li>to facilitate academic social policy analysis</li><li>to provide a freely available resource on public attitudes for the wider community of users in Northern Ireland</li></ul>NILT originally had a companion series which also began in 1998, the <i>Young Life and Times Survey</i> (YLT) (see under SN 33313), although the YLT methodology changed in 2003. NILT also forms part of the <a href="http://www.issp.org/" title ="International Social Survey Programme">International Social Survey Programme</a> (ISSP), although it does not do so every year. Unfortunately, the NILT team were unable to obtain full funding to run NILT in 2011, though YLT ran as normal that year. NILT resumed in 2012 - see SN 7408. In addition, two open access teaching datasets were created from NILT 2012, one covering Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) issues and the other covering  politics and good relations (see SNs 7546 and 7547 respectively).<br> <br> Further information about the NILT series may be found on the ARK (Access Research Knowledge) <a href="http://www.ark.ac.uk/nilt/" title="NILT">NILT</a> webpages.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br> The dataset records the responses of 2200 adults to the 1999 Northern Ireland Life and Times Survey.  Questions are grouped into 'modules' and this dataset includes questions on background, community relations, political attitudes, education, genetics research, social inequalities (this module is part of ISSP and is also archived in the German Archive (ZA)), transport.<br> Not all respondents were asked every module.  Although the survey included a module on pensions, it is not in this dataset.<br> <br> Standard Measures<br> ISCO codes, Registrar General Social Class.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="1999-10-01T00:00:00Z">October 1999</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2000-01-01T00:00:00Z">January 2000</collDate>         <nation>Northern Ireland</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Northern Irish adults</universe>         <universe>Adults aged 18 and over in Northern Ireland during 1999-2000.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Research and Evaluation Services</dataCollector>         <sampProc>One-stage stratified or systematic random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>Weighting factor used: WTFACTOR</deviat>         <deviat>(A)   3337 (target)   2200 (obtained)</deviat>         <deviat>(B)   2212 (obtained)   Weighted sample size</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>No information recorded</weight>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage.
